target_title: Wrong folder trashed when using right click->"Move to trash"

note.body:
as far as technical stuff, I am slightly familiar with vala and gtk stuff. I tried finding the code for the trash and it referred to "get_selected_item"

This might be retrieving the "hovered" entry somehow...you can see from this gtk doc entry that they refer to a distinction between 'selected' and 'activated' which could be a clue https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/method.ColumnView.get_single_click_activate.html

target_title: Wrong folder trashed when using right click->"Move to trash"

note.body:
here is a slightly better description of some behaviors

- there are no terminal messages
- i am not using the keyboard or doing anything extra. the only thing that i do that is maybe 'unexpected' is moving my mouse outside the bounds of the context menu, which changes the highlighted item as seen in the videos
- it sometimes deletes the file that is hovered
- it sometimes deletes the file at the top of the screen 

here is a screen recording that shows both behaviors, with narration


![out3](/uploads/c6a36b45b154fec8c4d3a65a08a07c9f/out3.mp4)


you can see from the video that:
- deleting the file that is hovered is seen more often when baobab is not fullscreen
- deleting the file at the top of the screen is seen more often when baobab is fullscreen

this top of the screen behavior may explain the "random" behavior that i observed in my initial post. it is not random but the entry at the top of the screen

target_title: Wrong folder trashed when using right click->"Move to trash"

note.body:
If @cmdcolin can confirm that it's related to the mouse hover (not click) only, that'd be an interesting discovery… and pretty wild, because even if I'm not one of the devs, I can't imagine why the code would care about the hover state.

On the other hand, if you see warnings/errors in the terminal, maybe this could turn out to be related to the failed assertions @automerisnaranja discovered in #134 … a null pointer issue sure sounds like something that could lead to chaotic behavior.

target_title: Wrong folder trashed when using right click->"Move to trash"

note.body: For me (Baobab 47.0) it's not random. The context menu action is applied to the last row that was hovered above, instead of the row that was clicked. So if I right click A, then move my mouse over B onto the context menu, the action I click on will be applied to B, even though I right clicked A.

target_title: Include a delete command that bypasses trash

note.body: IMHO, this is such a dangerous action that there would need to be a confirmation dialog to make _sure_ that you really are deleting the folder that you think you are deleting, and that 1) you did not hit the wrong folder by slipping with the mouse/keyboard, which does happen 2) the software did not misinterpret the folder you wanted, as seen in #157.

target_title: Wrong folder trashed when using right click->"Move to trash"

note.body:
The fact that your videos have such low framerates, and that the Baobab and Nautilus are not tiled side-by-side, and there is no voice narration, make it hard to know what's going on.

For instance, are you right-clicking directly onto the item to delete (to open the contextual menu) without any prior selection (ex: via the keyboard, with workarounds like in #65)? My hunch is that this could influence things.

Baobab does not seem to have much maintainers/contributors, so if you (or someone you know) can provide a merge request to fix this, it would increase the chances of this getting fixed.

target_title: Memory leak when scanning arbitrary directories

note.body: Hi there, you'll probably need to run it through Valgrind to find where the memory leak is. See this guide: https://developer.gnome.org/documentation/tools/valgrind.html

target_title: general: Some tweaks
window: Togglable side pane and adaptivity(-ish)

note.body:
Take 2: now the contents of the columnview can be scrolled horizontally! I think this is a pretty good compromise.

The only jank thing about my solution is that since we're using two separate ScrolledWindows, they both have their own overshoots, which can look a bit awkward, but I think it's not a big issue (especially since they scroll separately vertically). See video:

![Screencast_From_2024-10-08_20-48-10](/uploads/12a4e195e3018eaac41a5c9cc068f632/Screencast_From_2024-10-08_20-48-10.mp4)

metainfo: Expand and modernize
window: Togglable side pane and adaptivity(-ish)

note.body:
> Fix list overflow on mobile size (the contents of the columnview are too long and require more px than is available)

This one isn't as simple as it sounds. At the moment, as seen on the screenshot, the filename is completely invisible due to there not being enough space for it. And yet, we need even more space to fit the other panes...

This would probably require re-thinking which columns are displayed and how (e.g. hiding the "items" label in the Contents column, making the disk usage percentage bar next to the filename less wide, etc.). I suppose we could try to make the columns togglable... or hide one of them by default on mobile, though that's a difficult decision to make (and just plain difficult to do - pretty much all of the things I just mentioned would require rebuilding the entire ColumnView whenever the window size changes, or keeping two ColumnViews on at all times. (Or adding breakpoints to every column, which I'd imagine would get laggy fast with larger folders...))

As a first experiment, I tried to ellipsize the "Contents" column labels. While this does help a bit, it still isn't enough to keep the window size in check (sometimes it'll get to `362px`...), not to mention that it makes the "... items" text misaligned.

![image](/uploads/8e120805add9c8e9596d73732a45f87b/image.png)

Another idea I had was to move the filename *under* the progress bar. This does make it visible, which is nice, but it makes the fields look a bit uneven and makes it a bit more difficult to identify which row is which.

![image](/uploads/aa8ca907ae5947babd2a7c4eb1478ded/image.png)

~~It's worth noting that this did, however, make the window fit, so maybe it's not such a bad idea after all...~~ Nevermind, still gets to *`361px`* sometimes...

target_title: window: Togglable side pane and adaptivity(-ish)
